initial_results:
### Text snippet from document at k=1
... Data were pooled using the generic inverse variance method and expressed as standardised mean differences (SMD) with 95% CIs. Heterogeneity was assessed by chi (2) and quantified by I (2). Meta-regression models identified independent predictors of effects. RESULTS: A total of 41 trials (39 reports) were included. Pulses alone (11 trials) lowered fasting blood glucose (FBG) (-0.82, 95% CI -1.36 to -0.27) and insulin (-0.49, 95% CI -0.93 to -0.04). Pulses in low-GI diets (19 trials) lowered glycosylated blood proteins (GP), measured as HbA(1c) or fructosamine (-0.28, 95% CI -0.42 to -0.14). Finally, pulses in high-fibre diets (11 trials) lowered FBG (-0.32, 95% CI -0.49 to -0.15) and GP (-0.27, 95% CI -0.45 to -0.09). Inter-study heterogeneity was high and unexplained for most outcomes, with benefits modified or predicted by diabetes status, pulse type, dose, physical form, duration of follow-up, study quality, macronutrient profile of background diets, feeding control and design. CONCLUSIONS/INTERPRETATION: Pooled analyses demonstrated that pulses, alone or in low-GI or high-fibre diets, improve markers of longer term glycaemic control in humans, with the extent of the improvements subject to significant inter-study heterogeneity. There is a need for further large, well-designed trials.

### Text snippet from document at k=2
: To compare the antihypertensive effectiveness of sour tea (ST; Hibiscus sabdariffa) with black tea (BT) infusion in diabetic patients, this double-blind randomized controlled trial was carried out. Sixty diabetic patients with mild hypertension, without taking antihypertensive or antihyperlipidaemic medicines, were recruited in the study. The patients were randomly allocated to the ST and BT groups and instructed to drink ST and BT infusions two times a day for 1 month. Their blood pressure (BP) was measured on days 0, 15 and 30 of the study. The mean of systolic BP (SBP) in the ST group decreased from 134.4+/-11.8 mm Hg at the beginning of the study to 112.7+/-5.7 mm Hg after 1 month (P-value <0.001), whereas this measure changed from 118.6+/-14.9 to 127.3+/-8.7 mm Hg (P-value=0.002) in the BT group during the same period. The intervention had no statistically significant effect on the mean of diastolic BP (DBP) in either the ST or BT group. The mean pulse pressure (PP) of the patients in the ST group decreased from 52.2+/-12.2 to 34.5+/-9.3 mm Hg (P-value <0.001) during the study, whereas in the BT group, it increased from 41.9+/-11.7 to 47.3+/-9.6 mm Hg (P-value=0.01). In conclusion, consuming ST infusion had positive effects on BP in type II diabetic patients with mild hypertension. This study supports the results of similar studies in which antihypertensive effects have been shown for ST.

### Text snippet from document at k=10
... Assuming low incidence and relatively high diabetes mortality, total diabetes prevalence (diagnosed and undiagnosed cases) is projected to increase from 14% in 2010 to 21% of the US adult population by 2050. However, if recent increases in diabetes incidence continue and diabetes mortality is relatively low, prevalence will increase to 33% by 2050. A middle-ground scenario projects a prevalence of 25% to 28% by 2050. Intervention can reduce, but not eliminate, increases in diabetes prevalence. Conclusions These projected increases are largely attributable to the aging of the US population, increasing numbers of members of higher-risk minority groups in the population, and people with diabetes living longer. Effective strategies will need to be undertaken to moderate the impact of these factors on national diabetes burden. Our analysis suggests that widespread implementation of reasonably effective preventive interventions focused on high-risk subgroups of the population can considerably reduce, but not eliminate, future increases in diabetes prevalence.
thought_process:
As I delve into the query "Diabetics Should Take Their Pulses," my initial impression is that this topic intersects with dietary recommendations for managing diabetes, specifically focusing on the consumption of pulses. This makes me think of the broader context of nutritional advice for diabetic patients, which often includes discussions on glycemic index, dietary fiber, and protein sources. Though the user might be seeking a straightforward dietary tip, I sense there's a deeper inquiry into how pulses, as a food group, impact diabetes management and overall health.

Analyzing the results from the original query, I notice a wealth of information on the benefits of pulses in diets for diabetic patients. The text snippets highlight various aspects, from the positive effects of pulses on fasting blood glucose and insulin levels to their role in lowering glycosylated blood proteins when part of a low-GI diet. These findings underscore the potential of pulses as a critical component of dietary interventions for diabetes management.

To further expand this query and uncover a more comprehensive set of relevant terms, I will employ the Temporal Evolution Analysis technique. This involves tracing the historical development of the topic, identifying key milestones in its evolution, assessing the current state of research and practice, and projecting future trends.

Starting with the historical foundation, I consider the ancient origins of pulse cultivation and consumption, as well as traditional medicinal uses of pulses. The development milestones include the scientific recognition of pulse benefits in the 19th and 20th centuries, the introduction of controlled diets for diabetes management, and growing research on the glycemic index and pulse-based diets. Currently, the focus is on pulses as part of plant-based diets, their high fiber and protein content, and their role in personalized nutrition for diabetics. Emerging trends point towards precision medicine approaches, novel pulse-based food products, and the integration of pulses into digital health platforms.

As I apply the Temporal Evolution Analysis, I systematically move through its steps: 

1. **Historical Foundation**: I identify terms like "ancient grains," "legume cultivation," and "traditional medicine," which provide a backdrop for understanding the long-standing relationship between pulses and human health.

2. **Developmental Milestones**: Here, I note the shift towards scientific recognition of pulses' benefits, the incorporation of pulses into controlled diets, and the emphasis on glycemic index research. Terms such as "scientific recognition," "controlled diets," and "glycemic index" become relevant.

3. **Current Landscape**: Assessing contemporary practices, I highlight terms like "plant-based diets," "personalized nutrition," and "pulses as a source of protein and fiber." These terms capture the current understanding and application of pulses in diabetes management.

4. **Emerging Horizons**: Projecting future trends, I consider terms related to "precision medicine," "novel food products," and "digital health platforms." These terms indicate where research and practice are headed regarding pulses and diabetes.

5. **Temporal Term Extraction**: Combining terms from all periods, I select those that are historically significant, currently relevant, or indicative of future directions. This synthesis yields a comprehensive set of terms that reflect the temporal evolution of the topic.

Throughout this process, I balance the structured approach of Temporal Evolution Analysis with natural thought patterns, allowing for reconsiderations, intuitive leaps, and connections between seemingly disparate concepts. For instance, recognizing the historical use of pulses in traditional medicine leads me to consider their potential contribution to modern personalized nutrition plans, connecting past practices with future trends.

As insights emerge from both the structured technique and intuitive connections, I begin to see a clearer picture of how pulses have been, are, and will be integrated into diabetes management. The application of Temporal Evolution Analysis reveals not just the explicit benefits of pulses but also the implicit, nuanced role they play across different temporal contexts.

Synthesizing this information, I conclude that the most effective terms for query expansion, considering both the explicit and implicit aspects of the user's inquiry, would include "diabetes," "pulse consumption," "glycemic index," "dietary interventions," "plant-based diet," "emerging trends in diabetes management," and "personalized nutrition for diabetics." These terms capture the essence of the query's evolution over time, from historical foundations to future projections, and are well-suited for a BM25 index due to their relevance and specificity.
